video.title: DevOps with GitLab CI Course - Build Pipelines and Deploy to AWS
video.description:
This course will teach you how to use GitLab CI to create CI/CD pipelines for building and deploying software to AWS.

🎥 Course created by Valentin Despa.

📚 Course Notes: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-course-public/freecodecamp-gitlab-ci/-/blob/main/docs/course-notes.md
📺 Valentin on YouTube: http://www.youtube.com/channel/UCUUl_HXJjU--iYjUkIgEcTw?sub_confirmation=1
🔗 Valentin's website: https://www.vdespa.com
🐦 Valentin on Twitter: https://twitter.com/vdespa


⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️

⭐️ Unit 1 - Introduction to GitLab

⌨️ Lesson 1 - Welcome (0:00:00​)
⌨️ Lesson 2 - Your first GitLab project (0:03:03​)
⌨️ Lesson 3 - Your first pipeline (0:13:00​)
⌨️ Lesson 4 - Help, my pipeline is not working (0:23:32)
⌨️ Lesson 5 - What is YAML? (0:26:22)
⌨️ Lesson 6 - What is a shell? (0:35:12)
⌨️ Lesson 7 - GitLab architecture (0:37:50)
⌨️ Lesson 8 - Pipeline stages (0:43:14)
⌨️ Lesson 9 - Why do pipelines fail? (0:48:11)
⌨️ Lesson 10 - Job artifacts (0:52:34)
⌨️ Lesson 11 - Testing the build (0:59:02)
⌨️ Lesson 12 - Variables (1:04:33)
⌨️ Lesson 13 - What is DevOps (1:10:27)

⭐️ Unit 2 - Continuous Integration with GitLab CI

⌨️ Lesson 1 - Unit overview (1:16:53)
⌨️ Lesson 2 - Your first GitLab project (1:18:41)
⌨️ Lesson 3 - Building the project (1:22:05)
⌨️ Lesson 4 - Assignment (1:33:10)
⌨️ Lesson 5 - Assignment solution (1:34:43)
⌨️ Lesson 6 - How to integrate changes? (1:40:24)
⌨️ Lesson 7 - Merge requests (1:43:50)
⌨️ Lesson 8 - Code review (1:51:38)
⌨️ Lesson 9 - Integration tests (1:56:29)
⌨️ Lesson 10 - How to structure a pipeline (2:10:53)

⭐️ Unit 3 - Continuous Deployment with GitLab & AWS

⌨️ Lesson 1 - Unit overview (2:16:41)
⌨️ Lesson 2 - A quick introduction to AWS (2:17:14)
⌨️ Lesson 3 - AWS S3 (2:20:57)
⌨️ Lesson 4 - AWS CLI (2:23:35)
⌨️ Lesson 5 - Uploading a file to S3 (2:29:04)
⌨️ Lesson 6 - Masking & protecting variables (2:33:00)
⌨️ Lesson 7 - Identity management with AWS IAM (2:38:49)
⌨️ Lesson 8 - Uploading multiple files to S3 (2:47:54)
⌨️ Lesson 9 - Hosting a website on S3 (2:53:15)
⌨️ Lesson 10 - Controlling when jobs run (3:00:06)
⌨️ Lesson 11 - Post-deployment testing (3:07:03)
⌨️ Lesson 12 - What is CI/CD? (3:13:01)
⌨️ Lesson 13 - Assignment (3:16:47)
⌨️ Lesson 14 - Assignment solution (3:17:26)
⌨️ Lesson 15 - Environments (3:24:40)
⌨️ Lesson 16 - Reusing configuration (3:33:52)
⌨️ Lesson 17 - Assignment (3:36:57)
⌨️ Lesson 18 - Assignment solution (3:40:53)
⌨️ Lesson 19 - Continuous Delivery pipeline (3:44:15)

⭐️ Unit 4 - Deploying a dockerized application to AWS

⌨️ Lesson 1 - Unit overview (3:48:129)
⌨️ Lesson 2 - Introduction to AWS Elastic Beanstalk (3:49:25)
⌨️ Lesson 3 - Creating a new AWS Elastic Beanstalk application (3:51:48)
⌨️ Lesson 4 - Creating the Dockerfile (3:59:02)
⌨️ Lesson 5 - Building the Docker image (4:02:12)
⌨️ Lesson 6 - Docker container registry (4:09:27)
⌨️ Lesson 7 - Testing the container (4:15:59)
⌨️ Lesson 8 - Private registry authentication (4:20:04)
⌨️ Lesson 9 - Deploying to AWS Elastic Beanstalk (4:34:18)
⌨️ Lesson 10 - Post-deployment testing (4:45:54)
⌨️ Lesson 11 - CI/CD recap (4:50:29)

⭐️ Unit 5 - Conclusion

⌨️ Lesson 1 - Final assignment (4:51:37)
⌨️ Lesson 2 - Conclusion (4:55:16)

🎉 Thanks to our Champion and Sponsor supporters:
👾 Raymond Odero
👾 Agustín Kussrow
👾 aldo ferretti
👾 Otis Morgan
👾 DeezMaster

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://freecodecamp.org/news

topLevelComment.author: Kyle London
topLevelComment.text:
This is nice and well made journey, thanks for the content.

However I had to stop the video to make a comment cause I see so many people doing the same over and over. When you were starting server with serve and add & to get it in background and any task like this people default to going to next line typing sleep some random number. Now if you want command to wait EXACTLY the ammount of time or seconds as it is actually needed I would suggest people use && instead of & and sleep.

No:
serve -s build &
sleep 10

Yes:
( serve -s build & ) && curl -s http://localhost:300 | grep -ie "what i wanna grep"

Since command after && (in this case grep) will execute once the command before has executed successfully (in this case serve -s build).

If your server takes 2 seconds 1st time to run it will wait exactly 2 seconts and continue. If it takes it 6 seconds next time it will wait exactly 6 seconds. While sleep 10 waits 10 seconds exactly every time no matter how long it takes to start server.

topLevelComment.author: Jamie Carl
topLevelComment.text: Just up to the Gitlab conditional stages.  Curious why you used CI "rules" when there is an "only" keyword that makes it MUCH simpler?  So instead of defining some rule you can just say: "only: - main".

replies.author: Jamie Carl
replies.text: @Valentin Despa Thanks for the explanation!  Makes total sense.  I guess I should stop using "only".  :)

replies.author: Valentin Despa
replies.text: Thanks for your question, Jamie! While it is true that using only: would be quicker, the official GitLab documentation states the following: "only and except are not being actively developed. rules is the preferred keyword to control when to add jobs to pipelines." So I have included them here as later on, GitLab may decide to deprecate or remove only. I hope this makes sense.

topLevelComment.author: Andres Velandia
topLevelComment.text: Hi Valentin. Thanks a lot for the video. I have been following it thoroughly so far. Today, I have reached and completed successfully the Lesson 11 (Post-deployment testing). I have a question on the results of the last stage in the pipeline (post-deploy). Why do the logs show that the artifact from the build stage is being downloaded and - allegedly - used by the script in the post-deploy stage? I ask this because the referred script never states explicitly that it is using any artifact in order to run the test on the static site on AWS S3. It is only using an image so that it can run the curl command on the site published on AWS. Thank you in advance.

replies.author: Valentin Despa
replies.text: Let's have this conversation in an issue. Please include screenshots and as many details as possible. https://gitlab.com/gitlab-course-public/freecodecamp-gitlab-ci/-/issues/new?issue%5Bmilestone_id%5D=

topLevelComment.author: Murugesan Narayanaswamy
topLevelComment.text: Hi, Thanks for giving such a course free!! I have a question: In DevOps in AWS course, there is no reference to AWS devops tools like code commit, code build etc.. Does that mean GitLab is more feature rich than CodeCommit etc? Or AWS DevOps tools cannot be used to deploy outside AWS EC2 / Beanstalk servers?

replies.author: Valentin Despa
replies.text: The course focuses on GitLab but takes AWS as an example. CodeCommit is just managed Git. CodePipeline is probably comparable to GitLab CI and should integrate well with AWS. However, I am no CodePipeline expert to make a good comparison. Try them out and see which one works best for your needs.

topLevelComment.author: miguelv
topLevelComment.text: Hi Valentin, Thanks for the great course. Is it possible to programmatically create a branch as part of the job stage script? Then add the files to the branch?

replies.author: Valentin Despa
replies.text: It is possible to create a branch but we rarely need something like this. We don't use Git to store the output of our jobs (aka job artifacts). There are other tools that deal with that, like the Docker container registry or a package registry.

replies.author: Valentin Despa
replies.text:
Hi Thomas,

For the first part of the course, you need to fork (not clone) the repo. If you still have issues, please post an issue with the repo with the course notes.

topLevelComment.author: Danny Michelle
topLevelComment.text:
DevOps is a great skill to have if you are a computer science undergrad. Somehow people think it's not for beginners or students but don't believe them. Explore it and you'll realize how much it teaches you.

For instance, whilst I learnt about DevOps, I also learned about Cloud Computing (GCP and Azure) and Git. O also got more comfortable in using the terminal.

DevOps itself is a great thing to learn and to stand out as a computer science undergraduate

replies.author: Aldrick dev
replies.text:
@Valentin Despa yes I know about GitHub Actions just wondering to see which would be better suited for me. 

To give some context, I do Python web development as a hobby, aspiring to be a backend engineer but do think having basic CI/CD understanding is important. So the reason I ask is because I already use GitHub to host my software and I’m curious if Gitlab is better for CI/CD than GitHub.

replies.author: Valentin Despa
replies.text: No, GitHub and GitLab are two different tools. GitHub has something similar called GitHub Actions.
